now you can be as creative with these ingredients 
as you want but you need not wrack your brains

coming up with new things out of nothing 
hi generations of Thai people have created

ways delicious ways of putting these together 
okay and that's what I'm going to talk about

I'm going to talk about the structure of four 
major categories curries soups stir fries and

salads now you might be wondering what do I mean 
by a structure of a curry I want to give you a

quick analogy if you were to make a car you 
know for in order for it to be a card needs

certain things it needs wheels body and Ginnette 
cetera those are the structures but within that

structure you can have the body whatever color 
shape you want you can have a diesel or gasoline

engine you can have leather cloth interior the 
choosing so the structure serves as a template

to work from but the choosing of the details like 
what kind of meat how much herbs how much spice

that's for you to play with and that's you can 
customize it to your liking so let me talk about

in structure of a curry so you get a good idea of 
what I mean now curries in Thai it's called gang

and it's loosely translated to curry and I say 
loosely translated because there's no word in Thai

that would mean everything the word curry would 
mean there are some things that we would consider

a gang but you might not you might think that's 
more like a soup so here's the requirement for it

to be a gag first you got to have a paste you can 
pick whatever pace you like you can make your own

you can buy one but that's a requirement gang gets 
its flavors from a curry paste okay once you've

picked your paste then you want to choose your 
liquid you can have a coconut based curry which

is going to be richer or you can have a water 
based curry and use water or stock which is going

to be thinner and that's when it's going to look 
more like a soup to you now you can also choose

to have a lot of liquid or a little bit and make 
it more like a sauce rather than a soup so that's

completely customizable once you've picked your 
pace you pick your liquid you're going to pick for

lack of better terms I call them the chunks those 
are the things in your curry the stuff you eat

including the meat you can have a tough cut and 
then stew it for hours make it fork tender or you

can choose a tender cut or seafood and just cook 
it quickly when it's done it's done vegetables

some vessels are obviously not high vegetables 
but considering the fact that we are not in

Thailand and in the spirit of trying to eat local 
vegetables I would make yourself an exception and

use whatever vegetables you think would work in 
that dish okay so anything would work and then

finally finishing herbs like we talked about all 
the bezos and whatnot toss it in at the end and

then once you've picked that you're going to 
fiddle around with the seasoning obviously we

need salt salt comes from fish sauce if you're 
making a vegetarian curry you can use salt in

this in this situation a little bit of sugar to 
round off the spice and the saltiness and I put

tamarind in brackets because sour is not generally 
a major component in a curry but some curries have

sour as a component so that's something you just 
got to figure out what tastes better for you okay

so that is how you get to a Thai curry as long 
as you pick one of these choose how you want to

customize it boom you've got it you've made a 
real Thai curry alright let's move on to soup

soups in Thai is called Bob that's the prefix you 
may recognize name suggests Tom Yum or thunk ah

those are examples of our soup it looks very 
similar to a curry except the main difference

is that soup gets its flavor from an herb 
infusion like I talked about earlier big

pieces of lemongrass let it infuse the liquid 
is the same the choice is the same you can have

a coconut base you can have a water based soft 
base generally soups tend to be lighter so we

don't use all coconut milk because that is that's 
going to be too rich too heavy and you don't have

to buy it when you're sick of it so we usually 
mix coconut milk with some water once you pick

your liquid the chunks choices are exactly the 
same whatever meat you want whatever veg whatever

finishing herbs you want finally the seasoning 
we see a little bit of a difference here we

still have fish sauce we still have a little bit 
of sugar now we see in the acid component we we

see the use of lime and we used lime in soups 
and not in curries because soups are lighter

so it will benefit from the citrusy refreshing 
quality of a lime whereas if you put a lime in

the curry it'll be so overpowered by the the heavy 
spices that you know you might as well use hammer

so that is a Thai soup we're almost done moving 
on to salads here we need to do a little bit of

paradigm shift I had a little hard time trying 
to trying to describe it there's nothing in Thai

that means salad the word salad just has no 
direct translation because because a salad in

Thai cuisine let me say this is very different 
from a Western salad in many ways for example

there's no salad greens no leafy greens there's 
no oil no vinegar it's mostly meat and a little

bit of vegetables the only reason why I use the 
word salad is because these dishes are prepared

by tossing stuff together in a bowl that's pretty 
much what a salad is you may recognize YUM claw

and laughs these are the three types of a Thai 
salad you may recognize these names now the

structure we first need a protein protein ties 
out it's a very protein centric it will be the

direction of your salad will be based on this you 
can have any protein you want you can have ground

meat you can grill it and then slice it you can 
use cured meat like sausages you know shellfish

eggs and I put noodles here in brackets even 
though it's not a protein but sometimes we do

make a noodle salad and it would take the position 
of the protein in this case so once you pick your

protein then you pick your vegetables we don't 
have salad greens in Thailand so the vegetables

we use are nothing that wilt onions celery 
tomato peanuts I would throw it and throw into

this category as well but Thai style generally 
can last at room temperature for a long time

without wilting now herbs very very important 
part of a Thai salad sturdy and or finishing

herbs remember if you want to use 30 herbs like 
lemongrass kaffir lime leaves you want to finely

chop them so you can eat them comfortably in your 
salad finally the dressing now the dressing is

would be the determining the determining factor 
of a tie salad the distinguishing factor I should

say there's only one kind of dressing I mean 
where that creative unlike Western cuisines we

don't have ranch Thousand Island all that stuff 
there's one dressing and the dressing is fish

sauce lime juice usually in about equal portions a 
little bit of sugar and some chilies that's it now

sometimes there's a little bit of a variation in 
that there's no sugar sometimes the chili is dry

sometimes the chili is fresh the modern cook 
now gets creative and sometimes they use this

Thai chili paste and mix it into the dressing but 
that's pretty much as far as I seen a time style

that gets so and makes life simpler for you and 
remember the word salad does not translate into

anything so that might explain the difference so 
that is a Thai salad finally our last category is

a stir-fry you may recognize names such as pot 
that's the prefix if you go to Thai restaurant

anything has popped in front of it it is a 
stir-fry now as I said earlier the Chinese

people gave us the art of stir-fry so over time 
Thai people have added our own flair to it so now

there exists two major style a Chinese style and a 
Thai style Chinese sauce or fries the sauce would

contain things like garlic soy sauce oyster sauce 
it looks very much like Chinese food and then a

little bit of sugar I say soy sauce says because 
often there's multiple kinds of soy sauce involved

Thai style on the other hand would contain Thai 
things like curry paste the Trinity palm sugar

and fish sauce usually spicier now as to what 
you stir fry you can stir fry anything you want

the methodology the basic methodology of a stir 
fry goes something like this you start with your

aromatics and buy aromatics I mean your sturdy 
herbs your curry paste garlic shallots things

like that then you want to add your meat and then 
you add your vegetables then you go in with the

sauce and finish it off with any finishing herbs 
you'd like you don't have to have any meat you

can just make a vegetable stir-fry you don't have 
any you don't have to have any vegetables you can

just make a meat stir fry you do that a lot you 
don't have to have any finishing herbs you can

just finish it at the sauce and depending on the 
kind of meat and vets you use sometimes the order

of this gets reversed but generally this is the 
structure of a stir-fry so that's the four things

that I've got for you obviously we do more than 
just these four we also grill we deep-fry we steam

but I didn't talk about them because few people 
can grill the fry and steam on a regular basis at

home but if you got a pot and you got a pan you 
can make a soup a curry a salad and a stir fry
